Authors:
Samuli Lehtonen, Hanna Tuomisto, Maarten J. M.
Christenhusz
Title:
One history, two narratives â how do fern plastid and nuclear
DNA phylogenies compare?
Abstract:
Phylogenetic relationships of major fern groups are
currently well understood in the light of plastid DNA phylogenies.
Recently, also the availability of fern nuclear DNA (nuclear DNA)
phylogenies has increased, but these have covered low taxonomic levels
only. The deeper phylogenetic patterns inferred from plastid data have
remained untested with nuclear data. This reflects the lack of universal
markers to amplify and sequence low-copy nuclear genes in ferns. We have
produced taxonomically broad datasets of plastid and nuclear DNA
sequences in order to assess how congruent the inferences made on the
basis of these data are in relation to phylogenetic topology,
evolutionary rate shifts and the dating of divergence times. We
demonstrate that nuclear DNA topologies are generally congruent with
those obtained with plastid DNA, but the mean age estimates for lineage
splitting can differ widely. On the other hand, for most nodes the 95%
highest posterior probability distributions for age estimates were
partially overlapping. We suggest that interpretation of the results of
molecular clock analyses should shift from emphasising mean age
estimates to taking into account the full range of age estimates. We
observed parallel rate shifts in plastid and nuclear DNA evolution in
several fern lineages, corroborating previously observed rate
deceleration in tree ferns and rate acceleration in asplenioids. We also
found fast evolutionary rates in Ceratopteris and Elaphoglossum and slow
rates in Saccoloma.
